description: Leaders need to know how to express themselves with clarity and conviction--in a meeting with five people or in a public forum with five hundred. Whether you're writing for yourself or someone else, this course will provide the basics of speech writing and give you the opportunity to write, revise and deliver a variety of different speeches. You will also be given the opportunity to answer audience questions after your speeches. The emphasis will be on preparing and giving longer speeches where a prepared text or speaking notes would be advisable. In this performance course, you will examine and learn from great speeches--from the classics down to the present. Your speeches will be videotaped and you will receive feedback from both the instructor as well as your peers.
name: Speech Writing

values.comments:
Leaders need to know how to express themselves with clarity and conviction--in a meeting with five people or in a public forum with five hundred.  Whether you're writing for yourself or someone else, this course will provide the basics of speech writing and give you the opportunity to write, revise and deliver a variety of different speeches.  You will also be given the opportunity to answer audience questions after your speeches.  The emphasis will be on preparing and giving longer speeches where a prepared text or speaking notes would be advisable.  In this performance course, you will examine and learn from great speeches--from the 
classics down to the present. Your speeches will be videotaped and you will receive feedback from both the instructor as well as your peers.

A vast majority of students loved this “excellent” course that taught “a lot about speechwriting, speech making and myself.” Students believed that the course honed their writing and speaking skills in a way that will be extremely beneficially outside the classroom. Although students felt the course should have focused a little more on writing rather than speaking, overall, a lot of them seemed to find this course very useful and fun.

Professor Benedict was described by the students as “enthusiastic, warm, and having a deep passion for the subject.” Students felt that they really learned skills from him that they could apply to real life situations. In fact, they wished Professor Benedict had been more critical in his feedback, stating that he was oftentimes “too kind.” In general, it seemed that students developed a good rapport with Professor Benedict, referring to him by his first name and stating “everyone should get the opportunity to work with him.”

Students felt that everybody should take this class, regardless of major or school, as it offers skills that everyone needs. They generally liked the structure of the course, but wished they had been more of a focus on writing and more group work to improve the quality of the course.
